thread.title: Oregon college shooting will intensify state's debate over gun laws
thread.title_full: Oregon college shooting will intensify state's debate over gun laws

author: Jeff Mapes | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Oregon college shooting will intensify state's debate over gun laws
text:
Comments 
The mass shooting deaths in Roseburg appear destined to plunge Oregon back into another intense debate on whether to adopt tougher gun laws. 
Shocking gun violence at Clackamas Town Center in 2012 and Springfield's Thurston High School in 1998 each spawned laws expanding criminal background checks on gun transfers. 
The latest law – which took effect less than two months ago after a bitter legislative debate – expands background checks to cover private firearms transactions. 
Supporters of tighter gun laws expressed a new sense of urgency to press the issue again, perhaps in the Legislature's short February session. 
The National Rifle Association stayed out of the debate Thursday. Spokesman Andrew Arulanandam said it is the group's policy "not to comment until all the facts are known." 
State Sen. Jeff Kruse, a Republican from Roseburg and one of the chief opponents of this year's background-check law, said it was too early to know how the shooter obtained his weapon or weapons. 
But Kruse, coming from an area that has always strongly opposed gun control, said new laws restricting firearms don't solve the problem. Instead, he said, the state should focus on providing better community health treatment. 
"I would submit that if somebody wants a gun bad enough, they're going to get it," he said, adding that new gun laws "don't get at the element we're after." 
At the White House, President Barack Obama angrily spoke Thursday about the shootings as he once again tried to push the Republican-led Congress to expand background check laws nationally. 
"Our thoughts and prayers are not enough," said Obama, urging voters to judge candidates for their stance on gun violence. 
"We are not the only country on earth that has people with mental illnesses who want to do harm to other people," the president said. "We are the only country on earth that has these mass shootings every few months." 
Back in Oregon, gun-control supporter Jenna Yuille said: "I would be incredibly disappointed if we didn't see some action from our legislators coming out of this." Yuille became an advocate for more gun restrictions after her mother, Cindy Yuille , was fatally shot at Clackamas Town Center in 2012. 
Penny Okamoto, executive director of CeaseFire Oregon, said she is focused on what help and comfort her group can provide for people directly affected by the violence at the community college. 
However, she added, "we always will be coming back to the policy discussion" and would look at additional steps. 
Oregon voters in 2000 approved expanding background checks to cover gun shows. The latest background check bill was approved this year after national groups – including one financed by New York billionaire Michael Bloomberg – helped expand the Democratic majority in the Oregon Senate. 
Oregon was the sixth state to adopt tighter background checks after the mass shootings of children at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, according to Everytown For Gun Safety, the group backed by Bloomberg. 
Everytown and other groups have several possible legislative avenues. They've talked about legislation that would make people criminally liable if they fail to secure their firearms against theft. 
Some also talked about limits on the size of ammunition magazines. Everytown also pointed to a 2011 court decision that prevents Oregon colleges from banning guns on campus. 
Any new legislative drive on firearms laws – whether it occurs in 2016 or in the next long session in 2017 – could well meet strong opposition from Roseburg and surrounding Douglas County. 
Sixty percent of the county's voters opposed the 2000 background check bill, a higher percentage than in any county west of the Cascades. 
Sheriff John Hanlin – in the forefront of responding to the Umpqua Community College shootings -- testified against the background check bill this year, saying he thought it was "nearly impossible" to enforce. 
In 2013, Hanlin wrote a letter to Vice President Joe Biden , joining with other Oregon sheriffs who said they would not enforce any additional gun laws they believed were unconstitutional. He quoted Linn County Sheriff Tim Mueller as saying that politicians "are attempting to exploit the deaths of innocent victims" by impinging on the rights of law-abiding citizens to purchase "certain firearms and ammunition magazines." 
--Jeff Mapes
